ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed knowledge of the historiography of mental healthcare and rhetoric in the US and internationally from asylums to community mental healthcare to psychological and psychiatric theory.

We traced the history of mental healthcare around in the world, mostly in the Americas. I learned how to compare and critically analyze institutions of mental healthcare to imagine solutions in the future.
I learned a lot more about the history of asylums and how it relates to society's morals and thoughts.
I learned a lot about specific histories of mental illness treatment that I didn't know about, specifically the history of asylums in the Americas.

This course was incredibly fascinating! I think that in addition to acquiring knowledge on the general history of psychiatry, this course is also structured to have students engage in the skills needed for historical analysis and research. I think it's an incredibly necessary course for any student hoping to work in the discipline of medicine or psychiatry because it forces us to really reconsider the relationships we have with the patient-client dynamic.

Throughout the course, you develop a key understanding of mental health history and the pervasive role that race has played in the field. You explore the history of asylums while simultaneously comparing/contrasting the logic of psychiatry in their different contexts.

Provided insight on the history of mental health (mostly asylums) and many of its colonial roots. Discussion of a diverse array of locations throughout history and how the treatment of mental health has evolved/stayed the same
I developed an understanding of how mental health discourses have been used by larger oppressive systems throughout history from economic crises, colonialism, settler-colonialism, to neoliberalism.
I developed knowledge and an understanding of the history of colonial asylums
I learned a lot about the history of mental health and about the frameworks that have been used to understand this history.
By taking this course, I've learned about the modern mental healthcare institution and it's history.
History of asylums and mental health through Foucault, Gramsci, Fanon in many different regions (Vietnam, India, China, Senegal) through different decades; trace evolution and divergence of thought

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course is well structured in terms of the readings/concepts covered. It definitely challenges you to think about your own relation to mental health and the healthcare system as well. The beginning does spend a bit much time on asylums, and I think I was slightly more interested in modern day psychiatric institutionalization and practice. Profe is very receptive to student feedback regarding course framework though and does take into consideration student input.

The class was all strengths! The professor was an amazing lecturer--her explanations were very clear, she started lecture with a summary of the previous class, she bounced ideas off of students and the class was a very collaborative space of brainstorming ideas. I also enjoyed the assignments for the class including the student presentations and asylum essay. The professor was also so open to feedback and gave really great feedback in our assignments.
The course covers many topics and does so very well. The history laid out is very easy to follow.

Professor Carrillo is such a thoughtful instructor, and carefully curates the assignments and readings so we learn in a very clear way. I do wish we spent some time on cultural-specific treatments of mental health and not just colonial treatments, I know there is less literature on this but I am much more interested in it, and expected more of that based on the title of the course

I think that the course is incredibly interesting but the only real weakness is that it's an incredibly heavy reading load, which makes it really difficult to keep up and engage fruitfully. I think that there are a lot of ways that you can make a heavy reading load result in a productive conversation, which I think Professor really worked to try to experiment with! I think that that is the biggest thing about this course that made it really worth staying in is that Professor really wants to know how to improve the course and really wants to hear from students. She's incredibly passionate about the subject and wants to talk about it with students, so she tries a lot of different techniques to try to facilitate student engagement. I appreciated that we had several assignments spaced out throughout the semester and her suggestions for the assignments were incredibly helpful to get us started on them ahead of time. She invests a lot of class time into catching students up when she sees we might be struggling and is such an engaging professor that this course is certainly worth the time for. I think some ways that the heavy reading load could be made successful without reducing the reading load would be by assigning sections to groups in the class or highlighting particular sections she might want us to close read for discussion. I think she really tried to facilitate this by posting key terms before each discussion for us to consider during our read through. However, it was a little bit difficult to tell what the structure of the week was going to look like; I got a sense that this course had originally been formatted to be a once-a-week course because it was hard to tell when we were expected to have the readings finished by (ex. first or second day of the week that we would be coming into class).

Strengths: Professor Lopez-Carillo is beyond amazing - easily the best Professor I have ever had during my time at Yale. The material of the course can be challenging to understand but she makes such clear connections with the readings and is able to lay out the arguments, making it easy to understand if you didn't have time to read or just skimmed. The workload is not too much and is manageable so long as you plan ahead of time with other courses. The readings also offer a wide spectrum of viewpoints. Weaknesses: There is honestly no real weakness that I can say about the course. The one thing I will say is that the reading workload can sometimes be a lot, however, Professor Lopez-Carillo started to release key term guides after we had voiced this and that is one thing that I think can help alleviate some of the stress and would be helpful in future teachings of this course.

super great class with fantastic discussion. The professor was great about creating charts, timelines, and diagrams to visually aid discussion. Only weakness is that the readings were a lot each week--it was often difficult to read everything.

The strengths are definitely Professor Lopez Carrillo. She is very passionate about the course and it comes through with how she engages with students, leads discussions, and holds her office hours. The class was also very structured and organized, including discussions.
The material was interesting but got a bit repetitive by the second half of the course.

One of the strengths of this course is the seminar format that allowed for student to open about their own experiences and ideas that have shaped their perspective of the modern mental healthcare institution. I also loved how the course facilitated in-depth discussions about the philosophy behind mental healthcare.

One of the weaknesses of the course is the extensive readings that were, at times, a bit too difficult to conceptualize.

Strengths: the professor!!!!

Weakness: a smaller class size may better facilitate discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you are interested in the material or would like an engaging professor/classroom environment, this is a great seminar!

Yes! I would definitely recommend this class to any student, especially those interested in the healthcare services! I learned so much and the professor is so caring who made learning so fun and easy.
Yes!
Yes, the course is great if you are interested in the history of asylums and race and mental health policies and race.
I think history of mental healthcare classes are really important to take, and this is a great one. It was interesting, even as a senior ER&M major I was learning new things

Yes, 100%! I think that Professor is really open to changing the course according to student needs and I can certainly see that some of the challenges we faced this semester (like incredibly heavy reading loads) would be adjusted in the future iterations of the course. I think that if you're going into any sort of healthcare field, whether that is specifically mental health or not, this is one of those courses that you should take at some point because the content is incredibly necessary if you're going to be a practitioner. Professor: fantastic. Content: fantastic. Structure: experimental, on its way to being fantastic!
Yes, if you have the time for it. This class is absolutely incredible only if you are able to dedicate the time to it that it deserves.

Yes!!! Professor Lopez-Carillo is such a great professor and this course is so different from many of the ER&M courses that are offered. Learning about the history of mental health & diagnoses is especially interesting too.

Yes. Super great for psych/pre-med students looking to become more aware of the historically racialized/biased medical practices. Leminar style so skimming the readings can be sufficient to contribute to class discussion

Absolutely! As a person that has mental illness, I appreciate so much to have learned about how our current mental health system is constructed. It contextualizes a lot of the odd and uncomfortable things that I have noticed while being treated. I also enjoyed the readings a lot, Professor Lopez Carrillo is amazing, and our discussions were always put into a context where they had relevance. Thus, facilitating the process of how are making connections about how these histories inform us today.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student with genuine interest in the material, but I would warn them that it is certainly not a gut, so they should only take it if they can commit to fully engaging with the material.

Of course, I love Professor Lopez Carrillo and she has so much knowledge to share about this topic! She also does a wonderful job of connecting the ideas learned in this class with the broader themes discussed in Ethnicity, Race, and Migration.
Absolutely! Very important perspectives on mental health that are not typically covered in other courses
